title: 113_hr4625
content: The Act titled "Medicare Home Health Rebasing Relief and Reassessment Act" provides relief and reassessment of the rebasing of Medicare home health prospective payment amounts. The Medicare Home Health Rebasing Relief and Reassessment Act amends Section 1895(b)(3)(A)(iii) of the Social Security Act to suspend rebasing for a 12-month period after enactment. The Secretary shall apply subclauses without the previous sentence. Revision of Home Health Outlier Adjustment in the Social Security Act. Study conducted by the Secretary of Health and Human Services on alternative adjustment methods. The study will analyze the impact on Medicare beneficiary access to care from 2014 to 2017 under section 1895(b)(3) of the Social Security Act with and without the application of subparagraph (A)(iii). It will also examine the number and share of home health services. The study will analyze the impact on Medicare beneficiary access to care from 2014 to 2017 under section 1895(b)(3) of the Social Security Act with and without the application of subparagraph (A)(iii). It will also examine the number and share of home health agencies projected to have negative Medicare margins by 2017, including details on location, size, and type. Additionally, it will provide information on the Medicare beneficiaries served by these agencies, staff employed, and the counties they serve. The impact of the adjustment on small home health agencies, as defined by the United States Small Business Administration small business size standards, considering the economic impact of regulatory provisions. The analysis considers the economic impact of regulatory provisions and alternative methods for small entities, as well as other Medicare home health reimbursement reductions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment, based on a study on health reimbursement reductions. The report will include recommendations and a determination on whether to modify adjustments under the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will report to Congress within 6 months of the Act's enactment, with recommendations on modifying adjustments under the Social Security Act. The report will include the rationale for any decision not to use such authority.
